pronunciation: ENJOIN', [Latin injungo. See Join. We observe that the primary sense of join is to set, extend or lay to, to throw to or on; otherwise the sense of order or command could not spring from it.To enjoin is to set or lay to or on.]

definitions.text:
1. direct with urgency; admonish instruct with authority; command. Says Johnson, 'this word more authoritative than direct, less imperious than command.' It has force pressing admonition with authority; as, parent enjoins his children duty obedience. But has also command; as duties enjoined by God moral law.
2. In law, forbid judicially; issue direct legal injunction stop proceedings.This suit defendants disturbing plaintiffs.
